Sometimes it feels like that, doesn’t it! I’m supposing that it has to do with the visible failures of the institutions that we have relied upon for the last century or so (probably more, actually) to hold our societies together and guide our behaviors. These structures have not been universally supported, but the people who wanted to bring them down or change them radically have been in the minority and had less power than they now do. I don’t mean to say they are criminally involved, though those of us who are frightened would want to say so. I do believe that the insatiable desire for ALWAYS MORE, by governments and individuals, has prompted an amoral attack on these centuries-old institutions, religions, laws, governmental structures, societal norms, in the search for ever more profit, wealth, and power. So, what happens next? With our natural planetary systems in dire danger of collapse, who in the world can say!

Q: Has the world entered a period of insanity? As it was written, so shall it be: The most merciful thing in the world, I think, is the inability of the human mind to correlate all its contents. We live on a placid island of ignorance in the midst of black seas of infinity, and it was not meant that we should voyage far. The sciences, each straining in its own direction, have hitherto harmed us little; but some day the piecing together of dissociated knowledge will open up such terrifying vistas of reality, and of our frightful position therein, that we shall either go mad from the revelation or flee from the deadly light into the peace and safety of a new dark age. The Call of Cthulhu, By H. P. Lovecraft
